competitive_intel:
## Available Competitive Intelligence

- Competition description: `../research/description.md`
- 3 top kernel notebooks in `../research/kernels/`

data_findings.finding: Target distribution: 24.6% success rate (994/4040 received pizza), indicating significant class imbalance favoring negative class
Text features vary significantly: request_title avg 72 chars, request_text avg 405 chars, request_text_edit_aware avg 397 chars. Text length could be predictive.
User flair has 3 values: None (no pizza history), 'shroom' (received pizza), 'PIF' (paid it forward). This is a strong predictive feature.

web_research.query: How do Kaggle winners handle class imbalance in binary classification with 25% positive rate?
web_research.finding:
Kaggle competition winners typically tackle a 25 % positive‑rate binary problem by combining metric‑aware training with data‑level and algorithm‑level tricks — all of which are discussed in Kaggle forums and competition post‑mortems ([Kaggle Q&A](https://www.kaggle.com/questions-and-answers/473546), [Getting‑Started guide](https://www.kaggle.com/getting-started/467908), [Kaggle discussion on imbalance](https://www.kaggle.com/discussions/questions-and-answers/27589), [Neptune competition recap](https://neptune.ai/blog/tabular-data-binary-classification-tips-and-tricks-from-5-kaggle-competitions)).

1. **Pick an imbalance‑friendly evaluation metric** – use AUC‑ROC, log‑loss, or F1 rather than plain accuracy, and monitor it during validation ([Kaggle discussion](https://www.kaggle.com/discussions/questions-and-answers/27589)).  
2. **Resample the training set** – either oversample the minority class with synthetic techniques such as SMOTE/ADASYN, undersample the majority class, or apply a

web_research.query: What are winning approaches for combining text and tabular features in Kaggle competitions?
web_research.finding:
Winning Kaggle solutions for problems that contain both free‑text and structured columns usually treat the data as a **multimodal tabular** task: the raw text is first turned into dense embeddings with a pretrained language model (e.g., BERT, RoBERTa, or GPT‑4) and those vectors are then concatenated with the numeric and categorical features before feeding the whole matrix to a strong tabular learner such as LightGBM, CatBoost, or a gradient‑boosted tree ensemble.  AutoGluon’s multimodal tabular API automates exactly this workflow – it ingests raw text as a first‑class column, trains a pretrained transformer on the text side, trains classical tabular models on the structured side, and finally blends them into a single predictor that often outperforms any single model ([auto.gluon.ai](https://auto.gluon.ai/0.7.0/tutorials/tabular_prediction/tabular-multimodal-text-others.html)).  

Beyond simple concatenation, the most competitive pipelines layer **stacking/ensembling** and **LLM‑genera

web_research.query: How do Kaggle winners encode high-cardinality categorical features with 20K+ unique values?
web_research.finding: Based on the current search results, the available information only covers general advice for handling high‑cardinality categorical variables—such as matching cardinality between train and test sets, bucketing low‑frequency categories, and avoiding one‑hot encoding when there are hundreds of levels—but it does **not** specify the exact encoding techniques (e.g., target encoding, hashing, embeddings, etc.) that Kaggle competition winners use for features with 20 000 + unique values【3†L1-L9】. Consequently, a detailed, step‑by‑step description of the winners’ encoding strategy cannot be provided from the sources at hand.
